awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Harnessing the Power of the Phosphate-Binding Protein PstS to Recover Phosphorus
awd_abstract_narration:
1554511
Mayer

On a global scale, there is an overabundance of waste phosphorus with a simultaneous lack of commercially available phosphorus for use. This contradiction stems from the crucial role of phosphorus for the growth of all biological organisms, plants and animals. As a rate-limiting nutrient, excess phosphorus in the environment is responsible for eutrophication, the leading cause of freshwater impairment. Conversely, phosphorus is vital to global food security as it sustains high agricultural productivity. Worst-case estimates suggest that rapidly diminishing mineable phosphorus reserves could be depleted beyond the realm of economically feasible extraction within a century. In the face of this looming crisis, the recovery of "waste" phosphorus from wastewater and environmental surface waters is no longer a luxury, but an urgent imperative that is the focus of this project.

Unfortunately, conventional wastewater treatment is incapable of satisfying new sustainability metrics of capturing phosphorus at low levels and recovering it as a valuable resource. Therefore, the overarching project objective is to elucidate the fundamentals of phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein and evaluate phosphorus removal and recovery efficiency. This is directly relevant to the principal investigator's (PI's) career trajectory as it integrates nutrient recovery, environmental microbiology, sustainability, and STEM education. The pursuit of mutually reinforcing research and educational objectives establishes a strong foundation for the PI's future portfolio of research discoveries and educational advancements. The proposed research will provide the first exploration of phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein in the context of phosphorus sorption and desorption for controlled phosphorus recovery applications. The study will elucidate the fundamental basis of phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein and quantify phosphorus removal and recovery using two protein-based systems: 1) E. coli bacteria engineered to surface-express phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein, and 2) phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein immobilized on synthetic media. Preliminary data indicate that phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein can remove phosphorus, but basic research is needed to improve understanding of the basis of phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein binding and its phosphorus recovery potential. By enhancing the fundamental scientific understanding of phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein capabilities, this project will substantially advance sustainable treatment in the context of the joint criteria of phosphorus removal and recovery. This work is novel in that, for the first time, the potential for controlled phosphorus removal and recovery using immobilized and surface-displayed phosphorus-specific high affinity phosphate-binding protein systems in both water and wastewater will be investigated. The proposed research advances broader societal outcomes, including improved understanding of sustainable technologies; increased minority participation in STEM; and development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. The results will foster development and evaluation of sustainable biomimicry-inspired technologies for phosphorus recovery. This effort has broader implications for environmental water quality, wastewater infrastructure, mining, global food security, and associated economic and sociopolitical implications.

por.por_cntn:
On a global scale, there is an ironic overabundance, yet simultaneous paucity, of phosphorus (P). This contradiction stems from the crucial role of P for biological growth. As a rate limiting nutrient, excess P is responsible for eutrophication, the leading cause of freshwater impairment. Conversely, P is a non-renewable resource vital to global food security as it sustains high agricultural productivity (and there is no P substitute). Worst case estimates suggest that rapidly diminishing mineable P reserves could be depleted beyond the realms of economically feasible extraction within a century. In the face of this looming crisis, the convergence of the paradoxical dual identities of P as a pollutant and nonrenewable resource provides a compelling opportunity. Recovery of waste P from wastewater as well as environmental surface waters is no longer a luxury, but an urgent imperative. Unfortunately, conventional wastewater treatments are incapable of satisfying new sustainability metrics in diverse water matrices, including removing P to ultra-low levels and recovering it as a valuable resource. Thus, it is critical to develop novel approaches capable of selectively recovering P from a range of waters, thereby turning the costs of pollution abatement into an economic benefit.

 

This study assessed the feasibility of a biomimicry-based process, taking a cue from nature by harnessing the power of the P-selective, high-affinity phosphate-binding protein (PBP). The protein naturally captures P for cellular use via a Venus fly trap mechanism in which the protein hinges closed as it binds P in the pocket. This research developed and evaluated protein systems that featured high P capture ability, but then extracted the P for reuse applications rather than allowing cells to import the P. By providing environmental protection (P removal) while helping to close the human P cycle (P recovery), PBP systems offer a potentially transformative strategy with significant advantages over conventional treatment processes. The overarching project objective was to elucidate the fundamentals of PBP-P binding and evaluate P removal and recovery efficiency. This was accomplished via three specific research objectives: 1) Evaluate P removal and recovery potential of PBP expressed on the surface of E. coli bacteria cells, 2) Quantify P removal and recovery efficiency of PBP immobilized on the surface of resin beads, and 3) Improve mechanistic understanding of PBP-P sorption and desorption.

 

Through the course of this study, we successfully tested P capture and release using PBP immobilized on bacterial surfaces as well as in a cell-free configuration with PBP attached to the surface of resin beads. Both approaches exposed the PBP directly to the water matrix, facilitating P capture. The captured P could then be released in a controlled fashion using a basic pH solution. After P release, the PBP systems were able to regain their ability to adsorb more P, yielding a reusable, highly sensitive, and selective P adsorbent capable of both P removal and recovery.  Further, the PBP immobilization step facilitates use of the protein systems as filter-style treatment processes. We found that the cell-free system (PBP resin) offered greater control over the P adsorption/desorption process, and thus emphasized its use in the majority of the study.

 

The speed of adsorption and affinity for P binding using PBP resin far surpassed existing adsorbent materials, such that it exhibited exquisite selectivity for rapid capture of P, even in the presence of other potentially competitive constituents in solution. The PBP resin was effective in a range of water matrices, including simple lab solutions as well as more complex wastewater mixtures. These aspects facilitate P capture to ultralow levels as well as recovery of concentrated, high purity P products, which enhances the value proposition of the waste-to-resource product. Moreover, the high rate and strong affinity of P capture were demonstrated for the adsorption of not only phosphate (i.e., inorganic P or orthophosphate, which is the traditional target of P treatment technologies), but also soluble non-reactive P species that are difficult to remove using existing approaches.

 

This research advanced broader societal outcomes, including improved understanding of sustainable technologies and development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. The results foster development and implementation of sustainable biomimicry-inspired technologies harnessing PBP for P recovery from diverse water matrices. This project supported the training of a post-doctoral researcher, two PhD students, and several undergraduate research assistants. This project contributed to eight journal publications, which helped to advance knowledge within the field of environmental engineering and beyond while also supporting development of the researchers in preparation for their professional endeavors tackling grand challenges such as P sustainability.
